channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: Fighters Quit, U.N. Says
item.description: The head of the United Nations peacekeeping mission said that 8,000 fighters affiliated with a variety of armed factions had surrendered since the M23 rebel group was routed.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Roma Evictions Increase
item.description: The eviction of migrant Roma squatters by French authorities doubled from the year prior in 2013, according to a report by rights groups.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE

item.title: Lobbying Picks Up Over Bill to Toughen Antinuclear Sanctions Against Iran
item.description: Sixty-two multifaith antiwar groups urged the Senate to delay a vote, while supporters accused Iran of negotiating in bad faith.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: United Nations Memo: Mideast Strife Turns Trial on Beirut Assassination Into Another Fault Line
item.description: The trial in the 2005 assassination of Rafik Hariri in Lebanon is about to begin, but it has become another friction point in the Middle East’s sectarian showdown.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: A man shouted for help for the wounded after a car bombing in Beirut that killed former Prime Minister Rafik Hariri in 2005.

item.title: Now Online, Diaries of British Soldiers Detail Horrors of World War I
item.description: Britain’s National Archives has posted the first group of firsthand accounts of the war, but millions of more pages are still to come.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Arab Neighbors Take Split Paths in Constitutions
item.description: Tunisia and Egypt, the neighbors whose twin revolts ignited the Arab spring, are a dual lesson in the pitfalls and potentials for democracy across the region.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: On Tuesday, soldiers helped a man into a polling station in Cairo, where Egyptians were set to vote in the third referendum on the constitution in three years.

item.title: Obama to Place Some Restraints on Surveillance
item.description: President Obama will issue new guidelines to curtail government surveillance that include providing additional privacy protections for foreigners and residents.
item.category: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER and CHARLIE SAVAGE
item.media:description: President Obama spoke to reporters before a cabinet meeting at the White House on Tuesday morning. Mr. Obama’s speech on spying guidelines is scheduled for Friday.

item.title: Kerry Urges Syrian Rebels to Go to Peace Meeting
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry met in Paris with the president of the Syrian opposition coalition that the West is backing to discuss the peace conference in Switzerland.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: Rights Chief Assails Law as Roundup of Gays Begins
item.description: The United Nations human rights chief Navi Pillay condemned the Nigerian law, which gives anyone entering a same-sex union 14 years in jail.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Mexico Faces Obstacle in Curbing Vigilantes Fighting Drug Gang
item.description: Spokesmen for the vigilante groups said they would not give up their weapons until the government arrested the top leaders of a drug ring that controls part of the state.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN and PAULINA VILLEGAS
item.media:description: Vigilante forces trying to defend against drug violence paused their convoy on Friday after hearing rumors of an ambush.

item.title: Training Fighters of Future Across Gaza
item.description: A Hamas program aims to prepare high school students for what they see as the next inevitable clash with Israel.
item.dc:creator: By FARES AKRAM
item.media:description: Palestinian youths on Tuesday in Gaza City after completing a Hamas training program.

item.title: French Leader Brushes Aside Questions Over Affair
item.description: Invoking his right to privacy, François Hollande said that everyone suffers “difficult moments” but that the annual presidential news conference was not the place to discuss them.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: President François Hollande of France brushed aside questions about his personal life on Tuesday.

item.title: World Bank Is Expecting Widespread (if Still Possibly Turbulent) Growth for 2014
item.description: The bank’s economists expect growth to increase to 3.2 percent in 2014, and to maintain that level for the next two years.
item.dc:creator: By ANNIE LOWREY
item.media:description: A Chinese steel mill. The World Bank predicts growth for China in spite of concerns with its banking sector and overinvestment.

item.title: N.S.A. Devises Radio Pathway Into Computers
item.description: The National Security Agency has implanted radio frequency software in thousands of computers around the world to create a highway for cyberattacks, according to officials and N.S.A.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and THOM SHANKER
item.media:description: The headquarters of the National Security Agency at Fort Meade, Md. “We do not use foreign intelligence capabilities to steal the trade secrets of foreign companies,” an N.S.A. official said.

item.title: The Lede: Republican Ideas on Immigration Could Legalize Up to 6.5 Million, Study Says
item.description: “Half a loaf” proposals may put many more on a so-called path to citizenship than immigrant advocates have previously thought.
item.dc:creator: By JULIA PRESTON
item.media:description: A Dream Action Coalition demonstration last month.

item.title: Documents Spur British Inquiry Over 1984 Raid at Indian Shrine
item.description: Documents released after 30 years suggest that British special forces had helped draw up plans for the attack at the Golden Temple at Amritsar, India.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: India Ink: A Feverish Welcome for Indian Diplomat in Hometown of Mumbai
item.description: Several dozen supporters greeted the Indian diplomat Devyani Khobragade in Mumbai, in a gathering that was as much a show of support for Ms. Khobragade, who was indicted in the United States on charges of visa fraud, as it was a protest against Americans.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI
item.media:description: Devyani Khobragade, an Indian diplomat, was surrounded by supporters at a Mumbai airport on Tuesday.

item.title: Tunisian Constitution, Praised for Balance, Nears Passage
item.description: Legislators across the political spectrum and human rights groups hailed the charter, considered one of the most liberal in an Arab nation, as a triumph of consensus politics.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:description: Tunisians wave the national flag at a rally in Tunis marking the third anniversary of the country's revolution.

item.title: Thai Leader Vows to Keep Job Amid Protests
item.description: Antigovernment demonstrators marched Tuesday to government offices as part of a so-called shutdown of the Thai capital.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Antigovernment protesters stood outside the Thai Customs Department building in Bangkok on Tuesday.

item.title: DealBook: Japan’s Suntory Buys Jim Beam for $13.6 Billion
item.description: The move means such longtime American brands as Jim Beam and Maker’s Mark bourbons will be owned by a Japanese giant.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL J. DE LA MERCED and DAVID GELLES
item.media:credit: Luke Sharrett/Bloomberg News, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A bottling line of Jim Beam Maple bourbon in Clermont, Ky. The deal was for $13.6 billion, a rich premium.

item.title: Israeli Official’s Reported Criticisms of Kerry and Peace Effort Draw U.S. Rebuke
item.description: A news report that the Israeli defense minister thinks John Kerry’s efforts are naïve and messianic drew criticism from Washington and some Israeli leaders.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Scores Die in Ferry Accident as They Flee Violence in South Sudan
item.description: Reports said a ferry accident claimed the lives of more than 200 people who were trying to escape a rebel advance on Malakal, the capital of the oil-rich state of Upper Nile.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH

item.title: Central African Republic Violence Ebbs, but U.N. Warns of Flare-Up
item.description: The United Nations human rights office released a report implicating Chadian members of the African peacekeeping mission in attacks on civilians.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Euro Zone Factory Output Rallied in November
item.description: Industrial production rose by 1.8 percent compared with the previous month, ending a two-month decline, official data showed.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY

item.title: As Parents Age, Asian-Americans Struggle to Obey A Cultural Code
item.description: Asian-Americans are struggling to abide by a strong tradition in which they are commonly expected to care for their parents at home, but few institutions are prepared to help.
item.dc:creator: By TANZINA VEGA
item.media:credit: Jessica Kourkounis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Phuong Lu, right, quit her job at a nail salon two years ago to stay home and care for her mother, Doanh Nguyen, 81, when her symptoms of Alzheimer's worsened.
